VOL. XXX, No. 46
PRICE OF JUNE WEEK TICKETS TO BE FIFTEEN
DOLLARS
Cost To Seniors Will Be Thirteen
Dollars; Caution Money May Be
Credited Towards Ticket

June Week tickets will be priced
at $15 for all undergraduates,
with the exception of seniors, according to an announcement Saturday by Chairman DOH. Colt.
This is a substantial reduction
from the price.of tickets in former
years. Last year the price was
$17, while in the 1924, the price
was $5 more than this year. For
seniors the price of- tickets will be
$13. Of this amount $10 is ineluded in the class dues, leaving
only $3 actually to be paid. For
alumni, the price has been sef at
li), with the hope that this low
figure will encourage the support
of the old -grads."
Caution Money May-Be Used
Au arrangement has- been made
with the treasurer's office whereby the full amount of the caution
money will be credited toward the
price of a June Week ticket for
all undergraduates who attend.
By this method only .$5 additional
need be actually paid out by the
undergraduate.
One ticket will admit the holder
and his partner to all of the events
during June -Week, and in addition each person will receive a
leather bound program.
•
The aggregate. cost .of tickets if
bought separately for each event
will amount to over twice the price
for a ticket for the entire June
Week program.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1926.

MUSICAL CLUBS PICK
TWO NEW LEADERS
Edward B. Passano was
elected president and Charles
McElfresh• business manager
.of the Musical Club for the coming year at the annual
banquet of the club. Passano
was a member of the Banjo
Club during the past season
and McElfresh played in the
Blue Jay Orchestra. The
banquet was held last Thursday evening" at the Engl. neers' Club, Light and Red- .
wood Streets.
Passano and McElfresh
• succeed Gordon M. Stick and
- John Eager Howard as officers of the club.

ASSEMBLY
Major Ezra B. Whitman Relates His
Experiences In Engineering
Profession

BARNSTORMERS ELECT
TWELVE—TO BANQUET
Twelve new members were
elected to the Barnstormers
Club at a meeting held last
Sunday. The newly elected'
are: Margaret Swindell,
honorary member, Eugene
O'Dunne, Walter Broening,
Hadley S. King, J. Noyes
Northup, Marc Hollander,
Max Bertuch, Kenneth Dixon, Don Bolton, Carl Stissel,
Jerome Natt, and Taylor
Brady.
• The annual banquet will
be held at The Southern Hotel, Friday night, April 23,
at 7:30 P. M., and was not
held last Friday night, as incorrectly stated in the last
issue of the NEWS-LETTER.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1926.

IN DEFERENCE TO CUSTOM
If anyone were to scan the editorial colunis of past volumes of the NEWS-LETTER, which, by the way, is something that
no one except the editor ever does, he would find that at about
this time every year an editorial dealing with the state of
the weather would appear.
Each of them would describe, in terms varying with the
imagination of the writer, the beauty of the campus in spring,
the feeling of langour which the _warm breeze inspired in the
jaded spirits of undergraduates, and the lure of the tennis
courts baking under the blazing hot sun. All, however, closed
with the same dire warning, that unbelievable as it might seem,
examinations were fast approaching.
'But this year we are not able to truthfully describe any
such delightful conditions . Outside of a few fairly warm
days, spring has scarcely made itself felt. Winter overcoats
have not yet been returned to their accustomed moth balls;
lacrosse games have teen played_ in what seemed like football
weather; and even last Sunday it seemed that a blizzard was
impending.
However, in spite of the fact that the weather resembles
March, and it seems only a few weeks since the mid-years, the
end of the year is very near. Time has rolled around so
unobtrustively that it does not seem possible that the finals are
close at hand—and that's the insidious thing about it!

Please explain how, without
• any expense to myself, I may
derive a decidedly substantial
income by acting as your academic representative.

The honorary fraternities on the campus, those, at least
which have not lapsed into that pleasantly dormant stage that
precipitated the uemise of the late Sigma Upsilon, hold, we have
always thought, a very important place in college life. To
borrow a thought from the article on 0. D. K. which appeared
in the last number of the Intercollegiate World, they serve a
double purpose in that the recognition of achievement which if
is their primary purpose to bestow also serves as a' stimulus
to younger men, giving them a definite goal for which to strive.
And there is little doubt that membership in such society is
the aim, or at least the dream, of almost every under'graduate.
No matter how great an interest a man may have in his studies
or in other phases of undergraduate activity, the knowledge
that distinctive attainment will have public recognition as its
reward cannot help spurring him on. For honor in the college
world has about the same relative importance of wealth getting
in the world of business.
•
The NEWS-LETTER, then, wishes to heartily congratulate the
men who were initiated into the Tau Beta Pi last Thursday.
• Every one of them, we feel sure, is well qualified for a society
membership in which is considered the highest honor in the
engineering school, and which will mean so much in/their profesit nal careers.

PRICE OF JUNE WEEK TICKETS TO BE FIFTEEN
DOLLARS
Cost To Seniors Will Be Thirteen
Dollars; Caution Money May Be
Credited Towards Ticket

June Week tickets will be priced
at $15 for all undergraduates,
with the exception of seniors, according to an announcement Saturday by Chairman DOH. Colt.
This is a substantial reduction
from the price.of tickets in former
years. Last year the price was
$17, while in the 1924, the price
was $5 more than this year. For
seniors the price of- tickets will be
$13. Of this amount $10 is ineluded in the class dues, leaving
only $3 actually to be paid. For
alumni, the price has been sef at
li), with the hope that this low
figure will encourage the support
of the old -grads."
Caution Money May-Be Used
Au arrangement has- been made
with the treasurer's office whereby the full amount of the caution
money will be credited toward the
price of a June Week ticket for
all undergraduates who attend.
By this method only .$5 additional
need be actually paid out by the
undergraduate.
One ticket will admit the holder
and his partner to all of the events
during June -Week, and in addition each person will receive a
leather bound program.
•
The aggregate. cost .of tickets if
bought separately for each event
will amount to over twice the price
for a ticket for the entire June
Week program.

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1926.

MUSICAL CLUBS PICK
TWO NEW LEADERS
Edward B. Passano was
elected president and Charles
McElfresh• business manager
.of the Musical Club for the coming year at the annual
banquet of the club. Passano
was a member of the Banjo
Club during the past season
and McElfresh played in the
Blue Jay Orchestra. The
banquet was held last Thursday evening" at the Engl. neers' Club, Light and Red- .
wood Streets.
Passano and McElfresh
• succeed Gordon M. Stick and
- John Eager Howard as officers of the club.

Northup, Marc Hollander,

held last Friday night, as incorrectly stated in the last

HOMEWOOD, BALTIMORE, MD., APRIL 20, 1926.

IN DEFERENCE TO CUSTOM
If anyone were to scan the editorial colunis of past volumes of the NEWS-LETTER, which, by the way, is something that
no one except the editor ever does, he would find that at about
this time every year an editorial dealing with the state of
the weather would appear.
Each of them would describe, in terms varying with the
imagination of the writer, the beauty of the campus in spring,
the feeling of langour which the _warm breeze inspired in the
jaded spirits of undergraduates, and the lure of the tennis
courts baking under the blazing hot sun. All, however, closed
with the same dire warning, that unbelievable as it might seem,
examinations were fast approaching.
'But this year we are not able to truthfully describe any
such delightful conditions . Outside of a few fairly warm
days, spring has scarcely made itself felt. Winter overcoats

The honorary fraternities on the campus, those, at least
which have not lapsed into that pleasantly dormant stage that
precipitated the uemise of the late Sigma Upsilon, hold, we have
always thought, a very important place in college life. To
borrow a thought from the article on 0. D. K. which appeared
in the last number of the Intercollegiate World, they serve a
double purpose in that the recognition of achievement which if
is their primary purpose to bestow also serves as a' stimulus
to younger men, giving them a definite goal for which to strive.
And there is little doubt that membership in such society is
the aim, or at least the dream, of almost every under'graduate.
No matter how great an interest a man may have in his studies
or in other phases of undergraduate activity, the knowledge
that distinctive attainment will have public recognition as its
reward cannot help spurring him on. For honor in the college
world has about the same relative importance of wealth getting
in the world of business.
•

membership in which is considered the highest honor in the
engineering school, and which will mean so much in/their profesit nal careers.
